Introduction In this section 1 Introduction 2 What will my assessment consider? 3 Eligibility for support 4 What happens after the assessment? 5 What will I have to pay? How to have an assessment of your care and support needs There are lots of things that you can do for yourself, or to help a person that you care for, to be healthy, active and independent for as long as possible. You can choose to arrange this care and support privately, without help from the council. See our web page about staying independent for longer for more information. If you would like us to arrange or pay towards any care, you will need to have an adult social care assessment first to see if you are eligible for support. You can do this by contacting Gloucestershire County Council’s Adult Social Care Helpdesk . We will discuss your needs, provide information about support available, and arrange for an assessment, if required

Briefing note: What does the CQC assessment of Adult Social 
Care entail?  
 
This briefing note has been prepared to help  people and our partners to understand 
more about what the process will look like and how they may be asked to support the 
assessment . 
 
Background information  
The Health and Care Act (2022)  empowered the  Care Quality Commission  (CQC) to assess 
how well local authorities meet their duties under  Part 1 of the Care Act (2014)  using 
their single assessment framework . 
 
We asked the  Local Government Association  (LGA) to undertake a peer review of 
Gloucestershire in September 2023 - read the full report here.  
 
CQC have published full guidance on  local authority assessments , this briefing note does 
not replace their full framework which should be accessed on the CQC website.

Statement from Executive Director Adult Social

“Our self-assessment report has been co -produced with our 
staff, partners and more importantly with people we serve. It is a 
fair representation of what we do well, and where we need to 
improve. We are committed to working together to improve the 
lives of all people who require our help, their family, carers, and 
the organisations that support them.  
 
We welcome this assessment  process and hold the insight, 
guidance and challenge received in the highest regard as a way

Gloucestershire. As a Council and a service, we are committed to striving to ensure we can 
make the best possible support offer to those that need us.  That means in terms of value for

. CQC assessment of Gloucestershire Adult Social Care Adult Social Care in England is monitored and regulated by the Care Quality Commission , in-line with government legislation. The Health and Care Act 2022 gives the Care Quality Commission (CQC) powers to provide independent assessment of care at a local authority and integrated care system level. You can find out about the latest inspection of Gloucestershire County Council on our website. CQC also inspects and rates residential care facilities commissioned by Gloucestershire County Council. Social care policies and procedures To ensure we comply with the relevant legislation, we follow a set of social care polices and procedures which are published on our website. Last reviewed: 09/05/2025 Previous The journey through adult social care

CQC assessment of Gloucestershire Adult Social Care The Care Quality Commission inspection report for Gloucestershire Adult Social Care was published on Friday 31 January 2025. Read the report The Health and Care Act 2022 gave the Care Quality Commission (CQC) new powers to provide independent assessment of care at a local authority and integrated care system level. On 18 March we received our CQC Assessment notification, and on 8 July CQC confirmed their intention to start their onsite inspection on 2 September 2024. On these pages you can read more about our self-assessment which sets out where we are now against our vision of where we would like to be, and how we are preparing for the CQC inspection later this year

answer:
To request a social care assessment in Gloucestershire, you need to contact the Gloucestershire County Council’s Adult Social Care Helpdesk.

- **Contact the Adult Social Care Helpdesk**: This is the first step to discuss your needs and receive information about available support. The Helpdesk will conduct an initial screening and may refer you to a locality team for further assessment.

- **Assessment Process**: If required, the Helpdesk will arrange for an assessment to determine your eligibility for support. This assessment will consider your care and support needs.

- **Next Steps**: After the initial contact, a referral might be made to a locality team, where a Duty team will triage and agree on the next steps with you or your representative.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Gloucestershire County Council website at [this link](https://www.gloucestershire.gov.uk/health-and-social-care/adult-social-care/how-to-have-an-assessment-of-your-care-and-support-needs/).
